Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Negotiating Care in Intercultural Integrative Medicine

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Providing culturally appropriate care for diverse populations has become a significant challenge for health care systems. There is significant debate among healthcare professionals about appropriate methods of practice in intercultural integrative settings. Common approaches have included training traditional birth attendants and incorporating ethnomedical practices within biomedical facilities. But significant questions remain about the how intercultural communication and healthcare delivery are transformed through these interventions. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically-grounded scientific fieldwork, examines how biomedical practitioners negotiate medical authority and social inequalities within intercultural healthcare settings. The results of this research will be shared with healthcare professionals, and among anthropologists and other social scientists interested in studies of biomedicine and healthcare inequalities. Findings from this study will be presented to the participating clinic, and disseminated through academic and non-academic publications, presentations, and reports in English and Spanish with the aim of developing care outcomes and strategies for improving intercultural health care.

Trisha Netsch Lopez, under the supervision of Dr. Kathleen DeWalt, will explore how conflicts over the delivery of healthcare in intercultural contexts are reflected, reproduced, or contradicted implicitly within everyday interactions between healthcare providers. The study will take place at an intercultural health clinic in Ecuador, a setting internationally recognized by biomedical health professionals for its inclusion of intercultural healthcare in delivery methods. This research examines the most intrinsic challenges to culturally appropriate health programs: who has the authority to define the role of culture, the limits of participation, and the direct and indirect beneficiaries of such programs. It will also make important contributions to medical and linguistic anthropology by combining linguistic and ethnographic methods to explore the intersection of political discourses of health and everyday care encounters. The study will combine quantitative and qualitative linguistic analyses of maternal health appointments with policy document analysis and interviews with health care providers, health officials, indigenous activists, and community members. This combination of methods allow for a multi-level analysis to understand how the act of intercultural communication shapes/is shaped by political discourses of culturally appropriate health care and indigenous rights, as well as the needs and viewpoints of patients, providers, and the surrounding community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explores the central challenges to providing culturally appropriate care for diverse populations. National governments and international health organizations increasingly recognize that differences between patients' and their healthcare providers' beliefs, practices, and language can negatively impact health outcomes. Misunderstandings can cause mistrust, and cause delays or errors in treatment. To prevent this, governments are implementing policies designed to foster environments that respect these differences, adapt services to patient/community needs, and improve the health of the overall community. However, there is no consensus as to how these goals should be achieved. Some organizations emphasize communication techniques between patients and providers, while others incorporate ancestral and alternative medicines with biomedicine. As such, the development and implementation of culturally appropriate healthcare policies can often result in conflicts between providers, administrators, and community members.

Graduate student Trisha Netsch Lopez, under the supervision of Dr. Kathleen DeWalt, explored how such conflicts over the delivery of healthcare in intercultural contexts were reflected, reproduced, or contradicted implicitly within everyday interactions between healthcare providers and patients. This research examined the most intrinsic challenges to culturally appropriate health programs: who has the authority to define the role of culture, the limits of participation, and the direct and indirect beneficiaries of these programs. The study took place at an intercultural health clinic in Ecuador, a setting internationally recognized by biomedical health professionals for its inclusion of intercultural healthcare in delivery methods.  

The study found that interactions between biomedical providers, ancestral medicine providers, and patients were heavily influenced by the economic and social limitations of each individual, and how they perceived the limitations of others. For example, most physicians in this rural area work on short term contracts. This meant they often chose not to adapt services or advocate for patients or ancestral providers because they feared they would lose their job. Patients and ancestral practitioners found it hard to establish trust in the biomedical providers because they changed frequently, had little knowledge of the community and its challenges, and had little medical experience. Ancestral medicine providers, on the other hand, were highly regarded by patients for their experience and community knowledge, but their practices are rapidly disappearing as traditional apprenticeship teaching methods are being replaced by formal schooling. Although the Ministry of Health has made attempts to revitalize ancestral practices, they often do not take into account the needs of the practitioners themselves. Many ancestral medicine providers felt government officials only valued their practices as a token symbol or novelty, rather than a legitimate practice based on years of experience. Although scientific studies have supported many of their practices, and some have been adopted by the Ministry of Health, these practitioners felt they lacked the respect and political finesse to effectively change national policies. In summary, each group involved felt they lacked the stability and authority necessary create meaningful intercultural relationships that could significantly improve community health.

The data collection and analysis methods developed in this study united approaches from sociolinguistics and ethnography. This combination enabled the examination of how political discourses of health and everyday care encounters intersect. This combination of methods allow for a multi-level analysis to understand how the act of intercultural communication shapes/is shaped by political discourses of culturally appropriate health care and human rights, as well as the needs and viewpoints of patients, providers, and the surrounding community. The results of the study are being shared with the Ministry of Health, participating clinic, and ancestral medicine organization. Findings will also be shared with healthcare professionals and other researchers through publications, presentations, and reports in English and Spanish. The findings of the study are likely to shape the development and implementation of future healthcare policies, training programs, and community outreach. The lessons learned could easily be applied to other fields where positive intercultural interactions are necessary, such as law enforcement or education.
